cat5e cables question
cat5e cables question
#1.) What is the maximum speed of cat5e cables?
1 Gb/s
10 Gb/s
1 Mb/s
10 Mb/s
1 Gb/s
Correct!
cat
The correct answer is: 1 Gb/s.
Cat5e cables can run at speeds up to 1 Gb/s and are
interchangeable for speeds up to 100 meters. They are
the most common ethernet cable today.
Your current score for network fundamentals is \V[11].
10 Gb/s
Incorrect, cat5e cables cannot run 10 Gb/s
(10 gigabits per second).
cat

Cat5e cables can run at speeds up to 1 Gb/s and are
interchangeable for speeds up to 100 meters. They are
the most common ethernet cable today.

Incorrect, cat5e cables do not have a maximum speed of

interchangeable for speeds up to 100 meters. They are

mac broadcast question
mac broadcast question
#2.) What happens if a frame enters an L2 switch with
a destination mac address of 01-23-45-67-89-AB?
The frame will always drop
The frame will morph
The frame will broadcast
The switch will shut down
The frame will always drop
Incorrect, the frame will not always be dropped.
The correct answer is: the frame will be broadcast.
The switch forwards this frame out of its active ports
(broadcast). When the target reacts, the switch will
learn the mac address and update the mac address table.
The frame will morph
Incorrect, the frame will not 'morph'.
The correct answer is: the frame will be broadcast.
The switch forwards this frame out of its active ports
(broadcast). When the target reacts, the switch will
learn the mac address and update the mac address table.
The frame will broadcast
Correct!
The correct answer is: the frame will be broadcast.
The switch forwards this frame out of its active ports
(broadcast). When the target reacts, the switch will
learn the mac address and update the mac address table.
Your current score for network fundamentals is \V[11].
The switch will shut down
Incorrect, nothing about this scenario indicates that
the switch would shut down.
The correct answer is: the frame will be broadcast.
The switch forwards this frame out of its active ports
(broadcast). When the target reacts, the switch will
learn the mac address and update the mac address table.
duplex question
duplex question
#3.) What can one assume about duplex settings if there
are multiple collisions on a given switchport?
Interface is full-duplex
Interface is half-duplex
Switchport is shutdown
Native VLAN is still 1
Interface is full-duplex
Incorrect, full-duplex connections typically mitigate
collisions.
The correct answer is: half-duplex.
Half-duplex connections will introduce collisions and
reduce bandwidth.
Interface is half-duplex
Correct!
The correct answer is: half-duplex.
Half-duplex connections will introduce collisions and
reduce bandwidth.
Your current score for network fundamentals is \V[11].
Switchport is shutdown
Incorrect, frames will not be received on the
switchport if it is shutdown.
The correct answer is: half-duplex.
Half-duplex connections will introduce collisions and
reduce bandwidth.
Native VLAN is still 1
Incorrect, native VLAN is not relevant to this
question.
The correct answer is: half-duplex.
Half-duplex connections will introduce collisions and
reduce bandwidth.
collision domains question
collision domains question
#4.) How many collision domains are present in
this diagram? *note: These are switches, not hubs.
collision
2 collision domains
7 collision domains
3 collision domains
4 collision domains
2 collision domains
Incorrect, there are more than 2 collision domains
in this network.
The correct answer is: 7. Each line from a device
indicates a collision domain. A collision domain is a
network section where data collisions occur from more
than one device transmitting data at same time.
7 collision domains
Correct!
The correct answer is: 7. Each line from a device
indicates a collision domain. A collision domain is a
network section where data collisions occur from more
than one device transmitting data at same time.
Your current score for network fundamentals is \V[11].
3 collision domains
Incorrect, there are more than 3 collision domains
in this network.
The correct answer is: 7. Each line from a device
indicates a collision domain. A collision domain is a
network section where data collisions occur from more
than one device transmitting data at same time.
4 collision domains
Incorrect, there are more than 4 collision domains
in this network.
The correct answer is: 7. Each line from a device
indicates a collision domain. A collision domain is a
network section where data collisions occur from more
than one device transmitting data at same time.
vlan broadcast question
collision domains question
#5.) A L2 switch with 3 VLANs configured receives a
frame with an unknown destination MAC address. What
happens?
Broadcast to other ports in VLAN
Broadcast to all VLANS
Unicast to the router
Multicast to BGP peers
Broadcast to other ports in VLAN
Correct!
The correct answer is: Broadcast to other ports in VLAN
The unknown MAC address will be mapped to a device once
the switch finds a device with the corresponding MAC.
VLANs are separate broadcast domains.
Your current score for network fundamentals is \V[11].
Broadcast to all VLANS
Incorrect, VLANs are separate broadcast domains. A
broadcast from one VLAN will not reach other VLANs.
The correct answer is: Broadcast to other ports in VLAN
The unknown MAC address will be mapped to a device once
the switch finds a device with the corresponding MAC.
VLANs are separate broadcast domains.
Unicast to the router
Incorrect, a unicast to the router will only be
established if the device communicating has found the
corresponding IP on the router via ARP. However, the
question does not even mention a router.
The correct answer is: Broadcast to other ports in VLAN
The unknown MAC address will be mapped to a device once
the switch finds a device with the corresponding MAC.
VLANs are separate broadcast domains.
Multicast to BGP peers
Incorrect, BGP (Border Gateway Protocol) is an exterior
gateway protocol and is used for connecting autonomous
systems. It is irrelevant to this question.
The correct answer is: Broadcast to other ports in VLAN
The unknown MAC address will be mapped to a device once
the switch finds a device with the corresponding MAC.
VLANs are separate broadcast domains.
